Description: Mould-made amuletic figure in glazed composition, representing an Egyptian male deity; depicted as standing momiform figure, leaning back against a back pillar, maybe Khons (?); wearing a crown (full moon or sun-disc?) and maybe the sidelock of youth to the right side of his head; holding symbols of power against his chest; poorly modelled; no loop nor piercing visible (or preserved); remains of light turquoise glaze, very eroded; light yellowish cream fine core; feet separate; broken in several place and glued back together; very damaged.
Curator's comments: The amuletic figure is so damaged that it is difficult to recognise the deity depicted. It looks like the lunar god Khons, son of Amun-Ra and Mut who was revered locally in Naukratis. On amulets of Khons: Andrews 1994, 17, fig. 11c (better preserved example); Herrmann et al. 2010, 64 (type 28). Andrews, C. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.171) (phase 3)
